channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Some Unlikely Dealers Are Selling Weapons to Ukraine
item.description: New brokers are cashing in as the Biden administration quietly encourages private weapons sales to Ukraine. Oversight is scant in these shadows.
item.dc:creator: Justin Scheck
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier with a rocket-propelled grenade launcher outside of Kharkiv in the early days of the war. Ukraine has turned to private arms deals to meet its needs.

item.title: Ukraine says it has retaken more villages in the east and south of the country.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian fighters traveled through the recently recaptured village of Yatskivka, in the Donetsk region, on Tuesday.

item.title: Macron’s European Political Community Debuts in the Shadow of War
item.description: The French president envisions the European Political Community as a bold way for an independent Europe to flex its muscle. Whether Europe will follow his lead is unclear.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France. One of the president’s obsessions is ensuring that Europe not become a bystander to history, as he puts it.

item.title: Gun Ownership is Common in Thailand, But Shootings Are Not
item.description: In a country with millions of firearms, the authorities have long worried about the potential for more gun violence.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: A gun shop in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand, in 2020.

item.title: Here is a guide to Ernaux’s most essential work.
item.dc:creator: Joumana Khatib
item.media:description: Books by Annie Ernaux on display at the Swedish Academy in Stockholm on Thursday.

item.title: Christian Walker, Warrior for the Right, Now Battles His Father
item.description: Before his Twitter posts upended the Georgia senate race, Herschel Walker’s son already had a large social media presence reveling in contradictions.
item.dc:creator: Clyde McGrady and Kellen Browning
item.media:description: Christian Walker, center, at a Los Angeles event in support of Donald Trump in 2020. He has emerged as a conservative social media star who takes delight in provoking the left, and defending Mr. Trump’s MAGA movement.

item.title: Democrats Worry for Mandela Barnes as GOP Attack Ads Take a Toll
item.description: Mandela Barnes, the party’s Senate candidate, is now wobbling in his race against Ron Johnson, the Republican incumbent. Democratic nominees in other states face similar challenges.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: Mandela Barnes opened a lead in polls over Senator Ron Johnson in late summer, after he won the Democratic primary, but since then Mr. Johnson has risen in surveys.

item.title: Suddenly, a New Jersey Congressional Race Looks Like a Bellwether
item.description: If Democrats have a chance of holding onto the House, their path runs through districts like Tom Malinowski’s.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Tom Malinowski greets a voter at the J.C.C. of Central New Jersey in Scotch Plains.

item.title: How to Recycle a 14-Story Office Tower
item.description: Buildings are responsible for nearly 40 percent of the world’s carbon emissions. In Amsterdam, they are trying to create a blueprint to do something about it.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Camille Aguirre
item.media:credit: Max Pinckers for The New York Times
item.media:description: An emerging group of architects believe in designing not just for the life of a building, but for its afterlife, too.

item.title: Covid Death of Li Wenliang, the Doctor China Tried to Silence
item.description: A New York Times video investigation reveals new details about the death of Dr. Li Wenliang, a national hero who faced censorship after sounding an early alarm on Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Muyi Xiao, Isabelle Qian, Tracy Wen Liu and Chris Buckley

item.title: In Global Slowdown, China Holds Sway Over Countries’ Fates
item.description: The lender of choice for many nations over the past decade, Beijing now has the power to cut them off, lend more or forgive some of their debts.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A restaurant overlooking Beijing’s central business district. China is a prolific provider of adjustable-rate loans to poor nations.

item.title: I.M.F. to Lower Global Outlook as Recession Risks Rise
item.description: The head of the International Monetary Fund, Kristalina Georgieva, painted a dark picture of the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Kristalina Georgieva said that the International Monetary Fund would downgrade its growth projections for next year.

item.title: Elon Musk Offered to Buy Twitter at a Lower Price in Recent Talks
item.description: Before Mr. Musk renewed his $44 billion proposal, he and the company haggled in discussions that ultimately did not advance.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:description: Elon Musk sought a discount of as much as 30 percent from his $44 billion deal, people familiar with the discussions said.

item.title: Twitter Wants Assurances from Musk as Takeover Talks Resume
item.description: Elon Musk is back at the negotiating table. This time Twitter wants guarantees he won’t walk away – again.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Vivian Giang, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco
Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: They Wear Leather, Ride Motorcycles. And Protect Children From Abusers.
item.description: A nonprofit on Staten Island offers a nontraditional, “ride-or-die” sphere of protection for vulnerable youth.
item.dc:creator: Bahar Ostadan
item.media:description: Some of the members of Bikers Against Child Abuse, in Staten Island.

item.title: How Farmers in Colorado Are Taking Care of Their Mental Health
item.description: Aching from a string of farmer suicides and other mental health challenges, neighbors in rural eastern Colorado are learning how to check in on one another. But as the drought drags on, is talking enough?
item.dc:creator: Cassady Rosenblum and September Dawn Bottoms

item.title: Whoops! Behold the Republican Trove of Truly Terrible Candidates.
item.description: So much Senate strangeness.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins

item.title: More on the Firing of That N.Y.U. Professor
item.description: It’s really just a routine bureaucratic affair.
item.dc:creator: Tressie McMillan Cottom
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times

item.title: Herschel Walker’s Son Is No Hero
item.description: Christian Walker wants credit for calling out a sham campaign that he had participated in. But there are no laurels for him.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: Meet the Shadowy Groups Behind Britain’s Liz Truss
item.description: Britain has become a libertarian laboratory.
item.dc:creator: Sam Bright

item.title: Humility Is a Virtue. But Can Humble People Succeed in the Modern World?
item.description: Capitalism seems to reward self-interest.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images via Getty Images

item.title: A Plan B for Democrats Living in Red States
item.description: Sometimes Democrats should not vote for Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Vowell
item.media:credit: Illustration by Shoshana Schultz/The New York Times; Photograph by Scott Raichilson via Getty

item.title: If Putin Uses a Nuclear Weapon, How Should the World Respond?
item.description: U.S. officials say that the risk that the Russian president will break the 77-year-old nuclear taboo remains low. But he insists he’s not bluffing.
item.dc:creator: Spencer Bokat-Lindell
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by FPG, Drew Angerer, and Gavriil Grigorov via Getty Images

item.title: The Politics of Grievance
item.description: We look at Italy, the largest country in western Europe to elect a far-right government in decades.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni in Rome last week.

item.title: Why Is It So Hard to Hit the Brakes on Inflation?
item.description: The Federal Reserve has run up against a stubborn obstacle in efforts to lower prices: companies reluctant to give up fat profits.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Will Reid, Eric Krupke, Marc Georges, Lisa Chow, John Ketchum, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
item.media:description: The Fed has been raising interest rates to make borrowing for big purchases — cars, houses, business expansions — more expensive.

item.title: Where defending nature can be deadly
item.description: No region is more dangerous for environmentalists than Latin America. We explain why it’s getting worse.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:description: Indigenous land defenders detained a logger in Brazil, by many measures the world’s most dangerous country for environmental activists, in 2019.

item.title: How to Learn My Love Language
item.description: A Deaf man has been let down by every lover he’s ever had. This time might be different.

item.title: Kathmandu Finally Got Tap Water. After a Climate Disaster, It Was Gone.
item.description: A disaster that wiped out a decades-long project to bring pipe-borne water to Nepal’s capital shows the mismatch between slow-moving donor-financed efforts and rapid global warming.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Uma Bista for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents south of Kathmandu collecting water at a traditional stone spout, which works only during the rainy season.

item.title: Medical Care Alone Won’t Halt the Spread of Diabetes, Scientists Say
item.description: Now experts are calling for walkable communities, improved housing, and access to health care and better food, particularly in minority communities.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Brian L. Frank for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Garcia of San Francisco developed diabetes after a pregnancy almost 30 years ago. Though she’s vigilant, she can’t afford to purchase healthy foods like lean meat, fish and vegetables on a regular basis.

item.title: OPEC Move Shows the Limits of Biden’s Fist-Bump Diplomacy With the Saudis
item.description: OPEC’s decision to curb oil production was a signal that President Biden’s influence over his Gulf allies was far less than he had hoped.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Ben Hubbard
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Saudi Arabia’s decision to support an oil output cut by OPEC and its allies on Wednesday marked another step of distancing from the United States.

item.title: Fat Bear Week Is in Full Swing
item.description: Mike Fitz, a former park ranger at Katmai National Park and the founder of Fat Bear Week, used to keep “a facade of neutrality.” Now he’s naming names.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin

item.title: Why Does a Long Run Send Me Running to the Restroom?
item.description: Runner’s gut — which can include cramping, nausea and a sudden urge to “go” — can plague many runners during intense exercise. Here’s why, and how to avoid it.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Are Scented Candles Toxic or Harmful to Your Health?
item.description: When candles burn, they release various vapors and particles into the air, but research suggests that using them is safe.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Does Magnesium Help You Sleep?
item.description: Studies have found a link between low levels of magnesium and sleep disorders. But changing your diet may be a better option than taking supplements.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin

item.title: How Can Oats, Which Don’t Contain Gluten, Be Labeled ‘Gluten Free’?
item.description: Oats, water, even sneakers may be advertised as “gluten-free.”
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan

item.title: Does It Matter if I Eat the Stickers on Fruits and Vegetables?
item.description: They won’t cause you any harm, but there are reasons to remove them before taking a bite.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Coal Miner’s Daughter’: Bringing Loretta Lynn’s Story to Life
item.description: The 1976 book (and its 1980 film adaptation) helped the world see the country star’s remarkable resilience. The writer who worked by her side remembers his one-of-a-kind collaborator.
item.dc:creator: George Vecsey
item.media:description: Loretta Lynn in 1975, the year before her memoir, “Coal Miner’s Daughter,” written with The New York Times journalist George Vecsey, was published.

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
